intro: Galium pumilum var. hirtum, commonly known as hairy bedstraw, is a low-growing herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender stems and small, opposite leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces clusters of tiny, white flowers that bloom in the summer months. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its hairy foliage and delicate appearance make it a distinctive member of the Galium genus.
